bibl.title: Report: Yellow Fever in West Africa in 1922, by [s.n.] Gouzien, [1922]

div1.p: Gouzien reports on yellow fever in West Africa and discusses epidemics and their control since 1900. He stresses the continued need for mosquito control.

div1.head: Report: Yellow Fever in West Africa in 1922, by [s.n.] Gouzien, [1922]

p.hi: YELLOW FEVER IN WEST AFRICA in 1922

div1.p:
(Abstract of an article from the monthly bulletin of
the Office International d'Hygiène Publique for December, 1922.
The article is the report of an address given in French before
the committee of the Office International d'Hygiène Publique
at its meeting of October, 1922, by Dr. Gouzien, Medical Inspec-
tor General, President of the Superior Council of Health for the
Colonies, Delegate of French Indo-China to the committee.)

Yellow fever has reappeared this year along the West African coast,
the cases being sometimes isolated, sometimes in groups. It has traveled from
east to west following the Gulf of Guinea.

The first case was at Grand Popo (Dahomey) June 12, 1922; then cases
were reported at Anecho (Togoland) June 20; at Accra (Gold Coast) July 22; at
Grand Bassam (Ivory Coast) August 16; and finally as reported in a cable of
October 14, among the natives in Bathurst (English Gambia), thus directly
menacing Senegal.

The West African coast, especially Senegal and the Soudan, is one of
the oldest strongholds of yellow fever. The last serious epidemic in Senegal
was in 1900.

The author observed the epidemic of 1906 in the Soudan involving
forty cases with twenty-six deaths, when for the first time the prophylactic
measures against yellow fever outlined by the American Commission in Cuba were
used. The plague was stopped at Kayes, the port of embarkation for Senegal.

Since then only sporadic cases, or local epidemics quickly controlled,
have been reported in West Africa. The mission which the International Health
Board sent could not find a single case, although it was in the epidemic season.

Previous to the five cases which occurred in August, 1922, at Grand
Bassam, the last two epidemics on the Ivory Coast had appeared in 1890 with
twenty-one cases, and in 1903 with ten. After 1903 there had been only two
-2-
cases, one in 1913 and one in 1914.

Dahomey had its first case in 1905, its last, in Porto Novo, in 1917,
A slight outbreak occurred in Belgian Congo in 1917 also. Several scattered
cases have been reported in Sierra Leone, the Gold Coast, and Kamerun.

Yellow Fever has been crossed off the list of diseases attaining
epidemic proportions in the endemic African zone. It now only manifests itself
sporadically and these cases are controlled and prevented from spreading by the
anti-Stegomyia fight which is immediately undertaken.

To return to the slight epidemic of Grand Bassam, we have, up to the
present, received only fragmentary reports. Here is a summary of the facts.

On August 4 the proprietress of a hotel in Grand Bassam, who had been
sick for five days, succumbed to an attack of hemoglobinuric bilious fever,
which happens fairly commonly in these countries. The history and symptoms of
the disease were so clear - death coming in a syncope, the patient having gotten
up too soon, which is, in fact, one of the rather frequent terminations of the
malady - that this incident would not have attracted any special attention, if,
on August 16, exactly eighteen days after the beginning of this case, a lodger
in the same building had not shown symptoms, typical in this case of yellow
fever, to which he succumbed the following day. His room-mate (and bed fellow)
was confined to his bed two days later, August 18, but developed only an
attenuated case of yellow fever. Three cases broke out later, the last on
August 22; and September 9, eighteen days after the isolation of the latter,
the local order which had been issued, declaring Grand Bassam infected and fix-
ing the limits of the tainted area, lapsed by application of our new sanitary
maritime police order of June 7, 1922, fixing the period of territorial observa-
tion at eighteen days after the isolation or the death of the last patient.

As I have already stated, this lapse of eighteen days, between the
case of hemoglobinuric bilious fever, which resulted in death, and the first
authentic case of yellow fever, could have made a poorly informed practitioner
suspect that there was a relation between the two cases especially in view of
the coincidence of place. But, besides the fact that the symptoms of bilious
hemoglobinuria paroxysm could not lead to confusion (hemoglobinuria being, in
fact, very rare in yellow fever, where hematuria, although exceptional, is
more apt to be observed), the skin did not show any trace of icterus, even when
it was put in the coffin, and it is known that icterus is late in yellow fever.
An autopsy of the patient was not made, as it was judged purposeless.

On the other hand, the two Europeans who were the first smitten led
a rather mysterious existence and, most important of all, the investigation
proved that, violating the orders given following the discovery of yellow fever
on the Gold Coast, they passed the frontier rather frequently. It was without
doubt on one of these sprees that they must have become infected, as there is
constant communication between Grand Bassam and Assinie (Ivory Coast) on the
one hand, and Axim, Sekondi, and Accra (Gold Coast) on the other. And, although
this last place only was declared infected, it is well known that in a time of
epidemic many unrecognized and undiagnosed cases exist, especially among the
native population and particularly among the children, who are said to contract
a weak kind of yellow fever, which, however, would immunize them sufficiently
to explain the rarity of infection among the adult native.

It should be noted that the Noguchi serum was tried at Bassam, but
its effect seems to have been uncertain. It is of interest to recall in this
connection the excellent results obtained by Dr. Deprez in 1917 at Matadi, by
using neosalvarsan with his two last patients.

To sum up the situation there seems to have been a yellow fever wave
extending from Grand Popo to the Ivory Coast forest, a wave of which only the
crest was seen, that is, the authentic cases, while the chain of infection which
leads to isolated cases 500 or 1,000 kilometers from the coast is concealed.
Every effort must be made to break this chain and to find the permanent hiding
place of the Stegomyia. Meanwhile in these countries where yellow fever is
still endemic, the antilarval fight must not be stopped.

The author mentions certain of the prophylactic measures taken by
the Chief of the Health Service. The circulation of vegetables, and of any
other commodities susceptible of harboring mosquitoes was forbidden, travelers'
baggage was disinfected by sulphur vapor and trains were fumigated.

NOTE: Later information enabled the author to report five fatal cases in
the Soudan between October 16 and 28, at Segu-Sekoro, on the Niger,
more than 1,000 kilometers from the coast, and in November even
English Nigeria was reported to be infected at Wari, and also at
Lagos where a case appeared imported from Wari.

All this confirms the necessity of continuing the organization to
prevent yellow fever in these countries which are in perpetual
danger.
